If you want more Half Life 1, get Blue Shift. It's short, but so much better.

150473883.review:
It's okay, but very flawed.

There are some big flaws holding this game back. Some of them are:

- AI behavior/pathfinding is bad. This is more apparent here than in HL (or Blue Shift for that matter) because you often find yourself with multiple AI allies (sometimes up to 3), whereas in HL you usually only have 1 security guard tagging along. The maps also seem narrower (or they barely account for AI pathfinding issues) and you get frustrating parts where you have to babysit the AI if you want allies to go up something like a circular staircase, only for them to barely act as a meatshield for half a second against enemies that will usually outgun them.

- The game is buggy. Sometimes, reload animations will simply not play. It's easy to get displaced or stuck on terrain (to be fair, this one also happens a bit in HL) or something like the topmost part of a rope.

- Platforming can be frustrating. Just like in HL (all HL games, in fact), ladders can act like magnets. Heat exhausts can kill you if even a single flame particle touches you, and it's easy to misjudge the timing. Rope climbing *works*, but it's rudimentary and subject to bugs like getting stuck when jumping from rope to rope.

- Audio mixing tends to be questionable. There's no voice slider, which means dialogue often is muffled, and all SFX is grouped together, which is bad in chapters like Worlds Collide where the audio levels are fucked and the sound of the boxes being moved around is so COMICALLY LOUD that you have to turn everything down to avoid becoming deaf.

- On hard difficulty, enemies are HP sponges. This exacerbates the issues of certain weapons like the MP5 against human troops: black ops tank almost entire mags at point blank, but you can't afford the time it takes to fire *that much* otherwise you take too much damage in return. So even though you get 9MM ammo from them, you have zero incentive to use the 9MM weapons against them and have to leave the extra ammo unused (or you leave those lying around and backtrack for them later). There's a bad interplay of weapon use because the way of tackling some encounters is to simply quickly gun down big threats with something powerful like the M249 instead of trying to "trade" ammo. This either pads out the game (by giving an incentive for needless ammo backtracking) or leaves you with almost no ammo for some portions of it.


The game does have its share of qualities. At its core it's just Half-Life, and it experiments with it (usually successfully) by adding a few mechanics, some fun weapons, and a new story angle. There are some neat ideas underneath the messy execution. This would benefit greatly from a remake that fixes all the issues with the physics, pathfinding, audio shenanigans, etc. I'd love to see another game featuring Adrian too.

If you already played the other games and this is listed under those 85/90% off deals, then I think it's worth it despite its flaws. It's an alright game for what it is.

150455924.review:
The gameplay is great, but not as tight as Half Life. Considering Randy Pitchford made it, Opposing Force is surprisingly competent. Though the last few hours feel like blatant filler, and the boss fight is the biggest waste of time (easily the worst boss in all of the HL series).

The new weapons are welcome, but the squad concept is half-baked. Other than occasionally healing you, they are there solely to trigger scripted events. The rope physics are utterly broken, but that might just be a consequence of running this over 30 fps. The major problem is that the night-vision filter is the same color as the reticle and the weapon selection menu, so in the dark you not only can't aim, but you also can't see what weapon you are switching to, and this game has a lot of dark spaces. Gearbox didn't do basic QA testing evidently.

Unfortunately, the updated Steam version with widescreen support is broken as of writing, so the game may freeze or crash without warning. I think my save files might be corrupted, but I have no clue since running the game in earlier versions sometimes works. Similar bugs were present in the HL 2 DLC as well. For that reason I wouldn't suggest anyone buy this, sadly. What quality gameplay there is is not worth the headache. Buy it on disc if you must, but don't get the Steam version.

149788404.review:
Half-Life: Opposing Forces, man, it's like this epic expansion pack that dives deep into the Half-Life universe. Gearbox Software dropped this gem in '99, and it's a whole new angle on the Black Mesa mess.

You step into the boots of Corporal Adrian Shephard, this soldier caught up in the chaos. His story is happening alongside the original game, giving you a fresh look at all that madness. It's like a new puzzle piece in the Half-Life saga, and it's pretty darn compelling.

The gameplay, it's got that same intense vibe as the original Half-Life, but with a twist. You're packing new weapons, dealing with fresh enemies, and exploring different places. The level design? Top-notch, man. You're in for both familiar and unknown threats, so it keeps you on your toes.

Gearbox Software really nailed it. They kept the Half-Life vibe while putting their own spin on things. You can see the love and attention to detail they poured into this expansion.

Released in '99, Opposing Forces was a real treat for gamers, giving more of that awesome Half-Life action and expanding the story. If you're a Half-Life fan, this one's a no-brainer. Dive back into Black Mesa, and get ready for a wild ride!

Sir Sterling Silver Spoon here, at your service! I've embarked on countless adventures in the gaming realm, but none have left me as delighted as this gem. This game is a true masterpiece, and it has earned a special place in my heart (and my shiny silver collection, of course).

From the moment I picked up my trusty controller (or should I say, "silver spoon"?), I was whisked away into a world filled with wonders and excitement. The graphics are so vivid that I nearly mistook them for my own polished reflection! The gameplay is smoother than a freshly polished spoon handle, and the storyline is as engaging as a royal dinner party.

But what truly sets this game apart is the incredible community it has fostered. I've made friends from all corners of the globe, and we've shared countless laughs and memories. It's like having a virtual tea party every time I log in, complete with biscuits and good-natured banter.

In conclusion, dear readers, if you want a gaming experience that's as sweet as sugar and as satisfying as a spoonful of your favorite dessert, this game is the one to savor. It has truly earned the prestigious "Sir Sterling Silver Spoon Seal of Approval"! So, grab your "spoons" and embark on an adventure you won't soon forget.

147933580.review:
THE FOUNDATION OF GAMES

REVIEW 2 of 4.

This is a mini review of the Half-Life expansion , Opposing Force. 

The game tells a side story where the player impersonates Adrian Shephard, one of the military with the task of eliminating the Black- Mesa project and everyone in it. The game itself is an expansion of the original Half-Life, same graphics, slightly improved voice acting but with localization bugs throughout the game, a rather long story for the price of the expansion, and a rather large variety of levels and weapons. The real strength of this expansion is the variety it grants players compared to the original game, granting several special weapons compared to the original game. As mentioned above, the main problem I encountered concerns the voice acting, which often changes from English to Italian during gameplay, without an in-game option to change the language.
Overall a great expansion of the game that grants a couple of hours of playthrough.

147106369.review:
78% Score - Finished at 3 Hours

Gameplay (1.75/2): Still the same old good Half Life gameplay. I felt like the pacing was very constant, keeping tensions high. My only complaint might've been how scarce health had been when I'd constantly be either low on health or close to being one shot during some stages. Some of the new weapons that were introduced work really well, and are even wholly unique. But one in particular (spoiler: the barnacle) felt super jank and didn't always work. The same goes for the rope physics, sometimes you're climbing a rope and it works super well. Sometimes it's just annoying.

Story (2/2): It's nothing crazy but definitely a good follow up to the events of OG Half Life. Otherwise creating an entirely new bad ass character, Adrian, who has plenty of important roles to take on over the events of Black Mesa's end. My only curiosity would've been more on the premise- going to kill Gordan Freeman. But... that's why we have Hunt Down the Freeman.

Writing (1.5/2): I'm not gonna say much, I just put this in my usual reviews. But the writing matches the tone and atmosphere we come to expect of Black Mesa. Scientists, Freeman, yadda yadda.

Visuals (1/2): Usual old Half Life art style. I would say the areas introduced throughout the game were all distinctly characterized by new areas of the facility that implement background to enemies. However, I wouldn't say there was anything too notable that I remembered apart from the end zone maybe?

Audio (1.5/2): Score occasionally occurs, motivating you to go pew pew. SFX and voice work top notch and fun. Not all that much to stand out.

146821347.review:
es una expansión que amplía y enriquece el mundo de Half-Life de una manera que sorprende y emociona a los fanáticos de la serie. Aunque no es un juego independiente, logra destacarse como una experiencia única que agrega una nueva capa de profundidad a la narrativa y la jugabilidad.

Una de las fortalezas más notables de Opposing Force es su narrativa. En lugar de volver a contar la historia desde la perspectiva de Gordon Freeman, te pone en el papel del sargento Adrian Shephard, un soldado de las Fuerzas Especiales enviadas a Black Mesa en medio del caos. Esta perspectiva fresca permite explorar nuevos aspectos del incidente y entender mejor los eventos que ocurren en paralelo con la historia principal.

La jugabilidad también se enriquece con la inclusión de nuevas armas y enemigos. Opposing Force introduce una variedad de armas únicas y emocionantes, como el Desert Eagle y el Displacer Cannon, que añaden un giro interesante a los enfrentamientos. Los enemigos, incluidos los peligrosos soldados de las Fuerzas Especiales, ofrecen desafíos adicionales que requieren estrategia y habilidad.

El diseño de niveles sigue siendo sólido y mantiene la sensación de estar atrapado en una instalación de investigación en ruinas. Los entornos variados y la atención al detalle contribuyen a la inmersión, y la exploración está recompensada con secretos y recursos adicionales.

A pesar de ser una expansión, Opposing Force se siente como una experiencia completa y autónoma. Su duración y la calidad de su narrativa y jugabilidad rivalizan con la del juego principal. Además, ofrece una perspectiva diferente que agrega profundidad al mundo de Half-Life.

145930096.review:
it's hard to call this DLC when it's about the same length as the base game; it feels closer to a sequel than a DLC, which is impressive. That being said, if it were to be graded as a sequel it would fall flat compared to the original.

Almost all of the game is comprised of new maps and scenarios compared to the original, with a number of new aliens and military personnel to fight against. There's a fairly large amount of new weaponry as well, which is great. As with the base game, though, the new weapons are pretty hit or miss. Out of everything the barnacle hookshot is by far the most interesting addition; it works very well and is a fun tool albeit one that's used sparingly. The new black ops enemies are slightly less obnoxious than the original ones, which is nice. The new alien enemies were pretty roundly terrible; they detect you instantly the moment you enter the room and their projectiles are so fast you don't even have time to react. From a gameplay standpoint the new bosses are better than the ones from the original; the atmosphere of the final boss is much worse than for Nihilanth but the fight itself is much better, even if it's obnoxious how the boss makes no indication that you're doing damage to him once he's vulnerable.

One of the key gameplay mechanics is the addition of solider NPCs which are more prevalent and useful than the security guards in the original. Generally the NPC soldiers are great in a firefight (I only survived past the midgame because a single soldier tore through every black ops in the rail tunnel for me) but the pathfinding AI is absolutely abysmal. There are several points where you need to drag over an NPC to open a door for you; this is never fun and slows the gameplay down for absolutely no reason because you usually end up abandoning the soldiers right afterward anyway. This is, of course, a problem in the main game too where you have to occasionally bring a scientist over to a door, but it's a much bigger problem here since opening doors takes a solid 10-15 seconds and there's never any real narrative significance behind it. The radios that provide occasional plot were fine early in the game; by the late game it made very little sense for so many soldiers to even still be alive in Black Mesa given the odds stacked against them and how they supposedly had already pulled out.

The game's biggest fault is in the plot. Bringing the G-Man in to directly intervene in everything feels very off and misses the point of the character; that being said, it was still very early in the series before much had been established. The journey through the facility feels very disjointed; much more than the original, this game feels like a sequence of unrelated levels. The various connections to the original game feel shoehorned in; I would have far preferred to not see Gordon Freeman at any point. It overall feels like it failed to learn many of the innovations that Half-Life taught; I had to google the plot to understand what was actually supposed to be going on, unlike the original where the plot was conveyed intelligently through level design for the most part. 

Overall, it was a fun expansion pack of new levels and mechanics and enemies, and for its age is far above average, but it fails to seriously learn from or develop any of the ideas from the main game. 5/10

144318567.review:
Yeah, it's good. 

Half-Life: Opposing Force is one of the best games (or, expansion packs) that released in 1999. 

Opposing Force doesn't really focus that much on story. Yes, it does have some story, but Opposing Force is more gameplay-oriented rather than story-oriented. Opposing Force expands upon concepts and mechanics that the original Half-Life had, and it does so by adding in new content such as new weapons, new NPCs, new gameplay mechanics and a few other things too. 

If gameplay is the thing you care about most when it comes to a game, then Opposing Force is the expansion pack for you. However, if you care more about story, I'd recommend Blue Shift instead. 

Another thing I absolutely love about Opposing Force is that you don't anything at all about the main protagonist, Adrian Shephard. All you know is that he's a 22 year old H.E.C.U marine corporal. You don't know much about Shephard, but yet you still bond with him and guide him throughout the Black Mesa Research Facility. It's absolutely exquisite. 

9/10. Would recommend.

The art style has aged well, and I enjoy the sci-fi theme. The story is now told from the eyes of a soldier from the military, which works quite well. The tutorial was well made and funny, which is rare. Would definitely recommend if you enjoyed base game Half-Life.

144075108.review:
Half-Life: Opposing Force, the highly anticipated expansion pack to the revolutionary first-person shooter, Half-Life, brings players back into the captivating world of Black Mesa. Developed by Gearbox Software and published by Sierra Studios, Opposing Force offers an exhilarating new perspective on the events of the original game, delivering intense action, gripping storytelling, and fresh gameplay elements.

Set parallel to the events of Half-Life, Opposing Force casts players in the role of Corporal Adrian Shephard, a member of the Hazardous Environment Combat Unit (HECU). Tasked with containing the alien threat at Black Mesa, players witness the chaos unfold from the perspective of the military forces sent to quell the outbreak. This unique viewpoint provides a fascinating contrast to the experiences of Gordon Freeman, the protagonist of Half-Life.

The expansion manages to maintain the same level of quality and polish that fans came to expect from Half-Life. The graphics, while not revolutionary for its time, still hold up well and effectively capture the eerie atmosphere of Black Mesa's environments. The sound design is equally impressive, with haunting ambient sounds and the chilling cries of alien creatures contributing to the game's immersive atmosphere.

Opposing Force introduces a variety of new weapons and enemies, offering fresh challenges for players to overcome. From the powerful Desert Eagle to the versatile Barnacle Grapple, each addition serves to enhance the gameplay experience. The expansion also introduces new alien species that further expand the lore of the Half-Life universe.

Where Opposing Force truly shines is in its level design and pacing. The game expertly blends moments of intense combat with periods of exploration and puzzle-solving, ensuring that players are constantly engaged and invested in the unfolding narrative. The set pieces are memorable and the pacing keeps players on the edge of their seats throughout the campaign.

However, the expansion is not without its flaws. Some players might find the campaign slightly shorter than the original game, and the story, while engaging, doesn't quite achieve the same level of depth and mystery as Gordon Freeman's journey. Additionally, a few sections can feel frustratingly difficult due to unbalanced enemy encounters.

In conclusion, Half-Life: Opposing Force successfully expands upon the rich Half-Life universe by offering a fresh perspective and thrilling gameplay. With its engaging storyline, well-crafted levels, and captivating action sequences, this expansion is a must-play for fans of the original game. While it may not surpass the heights of its predecessor, Opposing Force remains a solid addition that enhances the Half-Life experience.

143522221.review:
Perhaps the pinnacle of expansions to games. Opposing Force is an expansion done right. It's an excellent game with only a small handful of shortcomings, but if you're looking for more Half-Life, this is the way to go. It is far superior to Blue Shift and reminds us of the days when Gearbox could do more than pump out Borderlands sequels.

Opposing Force still remains fun to replay even to this day, it's only real drawback is it's only half the length of the original Half-Life, but it makes up for it by introducing new weapons, new mechanics, and new monsters, keeping gameplay fresh but familiar. It stands still as a masterclass of expansions. It's a shame that DLCs and expansions of today don't hold up quite as well.

142805647.review:
THE  C O O L E R  HALF-LIFE 

The king of expansion packs, Opposing Force reigns supreme as one of the greatest add-ons to one of the greatest video games of all time. Instead of taking the safe route and doing the same game all over again, Gearbox Software expands on the gameplay elements of Half-Life and creates a consistent, better-paced product.

My favorite addition is the increased range  of weapons with stuff like the Xen portal gun and the massive machine guns that just mows down so many aliens! This game is much more action-focused than the original, with less emphasis on the tricky platforming and fun-ruining chores like the tram level in the middle of the original’s campaign. Opposing Force trims the fat of its predecessor in all the right ways. The story is passible, but having different characters experience the resonance cascade in each pack makes for a complete experience in the original Half-Life. Gearbox’s elaboration not only expands, but improves upon the foundation.

Great game. Required for all gamers.

142588682.review:
Half-Life Opposing Force is a first-person shooter video game released in 1999, and it is the first expansion pack for the 1998 classic, Half-Life. You play as Adrian Sheppard, one of the military specialists sent to the Black Mesa Research Facility to eliminate Gordon Freeman. This game brings a whole new single player action episode, as well as new alien opponents, weapons and environment.

One of the great features of Half-Life Opposing Force is the graphics. The level design and the environment of the Black Mesa Research Facility are stunning and very detailed. Not only that, but every weapon and enemy in the game is realistically designed, and makes for an intense gaming experience. The sound effects are also great, the sound of the weapons and the alien noises really add an extra layer of realism to the game.

The gameplay in Half-Life Opposing Force is great. The single player campaign is fairly long with 10 missions, and each mission is well designed and provides a great challenge. The missions require you to complete objectives, and they have a nice mix of exploration, puzzle solving and combat. The combat in particular is very enjoyable. You will get to use an arsenal of weapons such as assault rifles, shotguns, and sniping rifles. You can also use grenades, tripmines and various other tools to your advantage. The enemy encounters are intense and challenging, and you will have to be very careful to survive the onslaught.

Overall, Half-Life Opposing Force is a great expansion to the original Half-Life game. It has excellent graphics, sound and gameplay, and the various weapons, tools and enemies make it an incredibly immersive experience. If you are a fan of the original Half-Life, then you should definitely give this game a try. It offers a great single player action episode and provides a challenging yet rewarding gaming experience.

142531604.review:
It's got new weapons, it's got new aliens, and it's got a lot more friendly NPC's you get to commandeer around.
It's the Half-Life formula you know, but improved and refined. It's length hovers around 3 hours, but i think that actively works in the games benefit. 
The most enjoyable and noteworthy aspect is the level design. While HL had some areas which ended up looping you back into a previous one, the game mostly railroaded you in one direction. Opposing force has you constantly observe an area you need to get to from afar, and than has you look back at the place you came from, some levels are truly open, while some use this only as a small gimmick, but in general, the interactivity has been greatly expanded. There is a lot more different rooms and interactive gizmos to discover, as well as entire optional scripted sequences. In general, i find myself questioning the areas i inhabit a lot less than i did in the original HL. There is a lot more environmental story telling as well.
It's also got new music, and it kicks ass.
If you are into multiplayer, this is the expansion that introduced CTF into the formula.
It's still got the same jank, some people might argue about canon, some people are pissed off you don't just go around slaughtering everyone, but for those of you who just like Half-Life, this game offers very much the experience you are looking for, and more.

142038154.review:
Step into the shoes of a different hero and witness the gripping events of the Black Mesa incident unfold in Valve's mesmerizing masterpiece, HALF-LIFE: Opposing Force. This expansion to the iconic original game takes players on an unforgettable journey, introducing a fresh perspective and delivering an adrenaline-fueled experience like no other. Prepare to dive headfirst into the chaos and intrigue that lies within the walls of Black Mesa Research Facility as you join the ranks of the military and discover a hidden world of mystery and danger.

Opposing Force takes the captivating storyline of the original HALF-LIFE and spins it on its head, offering players a new lens through which to view the events. Developed by Gearbox Software, this expansion flawlessly captures the essence of the beloved series, immersing players in a thrilling first-person shooter with a touch of horror. The game introduces a host of new weapons, enemies, and allies, ensuring that every moment feels fresh and exciting. From the moment you don the boots of Corporal Adrian Shephard, you'll be thrust into heart-pounding battles against otherworldly creatures, all while uncovering dark secrets hidden within Black Mesa's twisted corridors.

The level design in Opposing Force is a testament to the incredible craftsmanship of the developers. Each area within the game feels meticulously designed and expertly crafted, immersing players in a seamless blend of tension and exploration. The haunting ambient soundtrack perfectly complements the eerie atmosphere, keeping players on edge as they navigate through dimly lit hallways and engage in adrenaline-pumping firefights. Opposing Force strikes a perfect balance between intense action and gripping storytelling, leaving players hungry for more with each passing moment.

HALF-LIFE: Opposing Force is an absolute triumph in game design and storytelling. Gearbox Software's expansion breathes new life into the Black Mesa universe, offering an experience that is both familiar and refreshingly different. From its captivating narrative to its meticulously designed levels, this title exemplifies the heights that the first-person shooter genre can reach. Whether you're a die-hard fan of the original HALF-LIFE or a newcomer to the series, Opposing Force is an absolute must-play, transporting you to a world of danger, intrigue, and unparalleled excitement. Strap in, gear up, and prepare to embark on an unforgettable journey into the depths of Black Mesa. Your adventure awaits!

141542804.review: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

141169985.review: Half-Life: Opposing Force is a great addon for Half-Life 1 and here's why. In Half-Life: Opposing Force, the player is not only shown an expanded history of the Half-Life universe, but is also shown new locations, weapons, and opponents. The game tells the story of the military Adrian Shepherd, who is part of the H.E.C.U unit (stands for Hazardous Environment Combat Unit). The protagonist after the crash of the osprey on which he falls into the Black Mesa complex where he was saved by scientists, after that the protagonist will have to get out of the complex alive, along the way fighting with various aliens from other worlds (I think the further story is not worth telling the branch, you can recognize it when passing ). If you liked Half-Life 1 and you would like to return to the Black Mesa complex again and fight with an even larger set of enemies using new weapons, then I can fully recommend this game to you personally, it brought a lot of positive emotions to me.

140486921.review:
⭐⭐/5 - It was ok

I recently played Half-Life Opposing Force, which I started right after playing Half-Life's "remake" - Black Mesa. It was exciting to revisit the Black Mesa facility and experience the story from a fresh perspective, especially after the immersive army training at the beginning. The first few chapters were enjoyable, even though the graphics and physics were not as impressive as in Black Mesa.

Happiness didn't last very long. Bugs and AI stupidness occupied my gameplay - I got stuck in walls a hell of times, and AI teammates tried to kill me a lot because of some glitchy behaviour. It became so frustrating that I had to force myself to finish the game. But by the end of the game, the gameplay became much more enjoyable, and I am not sure why. There were fewer bugs, and the final boss Gene Worm (nice guy), was a thrilling challenge.

Overall, I found the Opposing Force DLC to be overly tedious and less engaging compared to the main game and Blue Force. While I would recommend it to hardcore fans of Half-Life, I wouldn't suggest it to more casual players like myself. Skipping this DLC in 2023 won't take anything away from your overall Half-Life experience.

UPD: After this review and retrospective view of Blue Shift, I remembered in detail the new mechanics and bosses that Opposing Force introduced. So, if you're seeking Half-Life gameplay and epic boss fights, you will definitely enjoy this one.

This is either going to be a short or long review so stay along with this review. This is the second time I've played this expansion pack for the half life 1 games. The first time I played it was on my brothers PC and I liked it when it first played it. So pretty much the game takes place at the same time where you play was a soldier that take care of the aliens that have invaded black mesa and it gets more crazy as the game moves on. If you are going to play this game I would recommend doing boot camp because this expansion pack has some add ons that people would like. One being the new weapons like the desert eagle with a red dot and much 2 extra weapons that I wouldn't like to spoil unless people don't want ot be spoiled by anything from the game pack. It tooks me months to finish this game not because of how long it is but because of how hard it is sometimes. There are some new aliens that Gordan Freeman hasn't fought in the game and the new soldiers that just eat your bullets unless you use a more powerful weapon. The story is pretty good since you barely have to listen to it but the pacing in the game I feel like is great. This done by the game studio that made the game Borderlands and If you haven't played borderlands then check it out when you have the time.  Also another thing that I hated in the game is the difficulty. Some parts can be fun but most of the time it can get annoying when you aren't focused on the game or not taking it seriously. For me when it comes to the half life games I would say this one is the hardest one I played so far since I'm sort of going through a game marathon for the half life series (Including the ones many people aren't talking about). Also If warning for people that play this game. This game is a bit glitchy for some places like for example there were points when I was in a loading screen for a few seconds for a vent and elevator my legs got stuck and I had to no clip my way out of the game to progress on so If your going to get it this game with the valve collection then I would look up how to fix this problem.

After all that I give this game dlc expansion a 10/10.

139042660.review:
TLDR: An extra slice of cake, but it’s got broken glass in it. 

[b][u]General Thoughts/Overview:[/u][/b]

I remember HL:OF very fondly… Coming back to it, I’m not sure why. 
The plot is near identical to half-life, but taken from the point of view of one of the invading soldiers, who is somehow turned into a good guy. The big additions are new aliens, more guns, and squad tactics. Fight your way through different parts of the base, with a few familiar sites, and deal with the invasion on a different front. 
I’ve always wondered if this was a retcon, where the military suddenly isn’t an antagonist. The plot seems to try to direct it as such, shifting blame despite the events of the base game itself. 
still, onwards.

[b][u]Pros:[/u][/b]
[list][*] No Xen levels. Beyond a few brief sequences the game is blissfully short of Xen, which is a terrible positive, but it’s still a positive. 
[*] The game feels decidedly Half-Life. It feels put together with the same care and attention to detail as the first, but suffers the same flaws because of it. For its time, though, it made it a strong expansion.
[*] The new enemies and weapons all feel different and provide a new experience, expanding on the ideas of the base game. They feel well placed, and the only question that pops into my mind is ‘Where were they?’ Which is a standard issue when trying to fit an expansion inside the very same space as the original.  
[/list]

[b][u]Cons:[/u][/b]
[list][*] Saves are bugged, mouse is bugged, game crashes, and when things are running ‘smoothly’, they aren’t smooth. The game has issues performing at every step and it’s as frustrating as it sounds.
[*] Friendly fire, isn’t. The clinging to realism, where American soldiers spend more time shooting their allies than enemies, is laudable, but a bit on the chin. It was when one of my squaddies lobbed a grenade directly into the cluster of his team mates, who were in cover and not even in the same direction as the aliens, killing all of them, that I just decided to stop bringing the soldiers along. It improved my battle performance no end. 
[*] The extra weapons led to bloat for me, where I found myself cycling through all the menus looking for the gun I wanted. 
[/list]

[b][u]Suggested improvements:[/u][/b]
 [list][*] FIX. THE. BUGS. 
[*] Condense the weapons down into a meaningful few and ditch the rest. 
[*] Give the AI some AI, so they can be of use.
[/list]


[b][u]Overall Recommendation:[/u][/b]

Overall I’d give this a miss these days. 

It doesn’t bring much to the story, it doesn’t play hugely well, and it just isn’t all that much fun. It’s the leftovers of a great meal that’s been left out overnight - it contains all the right elements, all the same tasty bits, but they just aren’t the same. 

But if you [i]really[/i] want a little more? It'll do it for you just fine.

138975240.review:
Este Opposing Force junto a Blue Shift forma parte de las 2 expansiones oficiales del primer Half Life, donde volvemos a las instalaciones de Black Mesa para vivir la aventura desde otros puntos de vista completamente diferentes a los de Gordon Freeman, protagonista del primer juego, seremos en este caso el cabo Shepard, miembro de los marines de USA y enfrentándonos directamente a los alienígenas con gran variedad de armamento.

Es un juego más directo que el propio Half Life entre otros motivos por ser mucho más corto, la historia la van narrando los personajes que nos encontramos por el camino y nosotros solo debemos centrarnos en abrirnos paso y disparar, aunque habrá pequeños puzzles muy sencillos siendo lo más habitual un botón o rejilla escondido en la sala. Gráficamente se siente muy anticuado y no será extraño ver objetos que se traban con otros, desaparecen, etc, siendo lo más molesto una ocasión donde debía acompañar a un científico para que abriese una puerta pero este se quedó atascado en una puerta anterior, obligándome a cargar la partida más atrás y repetir todo. También hay bugs importantes en el sonido, especialmente las voces que son casi siempre en inglés pero de vez en cuando te sorprende alguna traducida.

Es un juego muy bueno, entretiene de principio a fin, pero hoy en día hay que aceptar sus limitaciones técnicas si queremos disfrutarlo.

138652118.review: Solid Half-Life expansion. Takes a very interesting perspective and trek through the Black Mesa facility. It was really fun getting to play as a faction you fight against in the original Half-Life. The new guns and enemies were super cool and mixed up the formula a bit. There were a couple plot points that didn't quite make sense to me like why the HECU soldiers were killing the scientists after they crash landed in the original Half-Life and weren't really shown doing that in this game and some other small stuff but overall I liked the further story context this game added to the HECU. I also think the level design was on point (still not as great as Blue Shift but really good and better than the base Half-Life game). It was also really cool how they tried to introduce squad mechanics with your AI teammates (it didn't always work perfectly but it was awesome when it did work). I do wish this game's story interconnected with the main Half-Life story more liked they did with Blue Shift (I really liked the Gordon cameos) but there where still some cool moments like, "FORGET ABOUT FREEMAN!". Overall a solid expansion with some cool levels and a really interesting ending (I wonder if it will be utilized at all in the other Half-Life games) that is sure to have had and continue to please fans of the original Half-Life.

138111783.review:
TL;DR. Opposing Force is a drab, lifeless mod that tries to stuff far too many ideas in to a small amount of play time. In general it feels like amateurs made it and indulged themselves whilst doing it. I'd avoid, as it's not very engaging to play, and play other games/HL mods instead. e.g. Go play 'Echoes' or 'They Hunger'.

In full:

When I played this in my yoot, I loved it. Half-Life was amazing, this was more HL, therefore it was amazing. Though looking back I barely remember anything other than the nightvision and the machine gun. I don't even remember the bosses. Could that be because it's simply been 20 years?

Well, now as I play it, 20 years on, I see how flawed asnd forgettable it is. Playing it on the back of HL1 it feels completely amatuerish. I've played _a lot_ of HL mods and TCs over the years, both single- and multi-player, and this really pales in comparison to a lot of them.

The mod is completely uninspired. It relies mainly on taking familiar places, set-pieces, weapons and enemies from HL, giving them a slight twist, and then repackaging them for you. However they didn't understand the ethos Valve had when making Half-Life, and this is clear from just the training room, e.g. you're forced to listen to huge amount of cliche drill sergeant chatter, whereas the original HL hazard course practically allowed you to speed run the entire thing. 


It's clear when playing Half-Life that a huge amount of love and attention went into each level, making every area feel alive and like a "real" place, and a large amount of testing went in to make the subtle cues that direct the player's flow state work like magic. We'd come to know such polish as a hallmark of Valve. 

No such care has been taken with the majority of the levels in this game. OP4 simply does not have the je ne sais quoi of Half-life. The vast majority of the levels are boring, square boxes with the wrong footsteps sounds applied to them and ZERO atmospheric sounds applied. You spend the vast majority of the game clumping around listening to that classic "half-life concrete footstep" sounds. It rarely tries to drop those timely music tracks that HL performed so well just before a battle or something interesting. Most of the major "set piece" battles were a thrill to take-part in in HL, whereas in OP4 they're just boring shooting galleries. 

Gearbox also often made that rookie HL mapper mistake of trying to make large open areas, which doesn't work well with HL's BSP tree engine, as it will happily bring a modern computer to it's knees if you give it an open enough arena. So I imagine that's why all of those open arenas are so square and boring -- they were desperate trying to go "big" whilst also saving on brushes and portals. Valve knew HL's limitations and allowed them to guide the level design, but I guess Gearbox's short turnaround time on making the game meant they lacked any such experience, and it's obviously something the HL community had yet to learn by the time of OP4's release.

But even ignoring the engine problems Gearbox show a general lack of experience in designing fun experiences. In general OP4 makes the mistake of adding "more more more" without any tact or sense on how to apply that. It's completely misguided and leaves everything feeling crowded. A good example is it adds a large number of weapons and keeps the majority of the old ones. You have fully stocked roster. But you have so many that you can barely use them all before completing the game, and it makes managing battles with HL's inventory a pain as now you have 2 more categories and each category has a million weapons. 

They clearly had more ideas than production budget when developing this mod and it's a classic example of scope creep.

Other short examples of Gearbox's eyes being bigger than their belly: 

* "Let's have them play the soldier!" Cool. But you completely forget to address the whole "shooting civilians" thing. Why is Shepherd nice but the ones we see in HL will happily shoot everything?

* The rope system. You use it like, twice in the entire game. It's a colossal waste of development time and the player's time learning it. It also looks stupid.

* The squad system is fun, but rarely serves any functional purpose.

* The portal gun is beyond useless. It effectively converts 40 uranium into a few health packs or batteries. But after the 5th or so Xen map it starts to recycle them and doesn't even repopulate the spawns, meaning the portal gun's second fire stops being useful 1/3 of the way through the game! But those Xen levels are clearly loaded into each main map, as the portal is instant with no loading, which presumably also contributed to the memory pressure and hence their more drab main environments. The Xen levels themselves are also drab, flat and empty, I assume for the same reason. There's very little Xen flora or fauna when compared to stock Xen.

* Also the Xen levels have the wrong gravity? You don't float as much. 

* It added a nightvision mode, in lieu of the flashlight, but it's ugly and useless and the times when it IS requires are really tedious.

* The monsters and weapons themselves are fun, however. Except the two melee weapons. Why add a knife AND a wrench? Especially as the wrench is redundant -- the knife does a better job at killing monsters AND at smashing boxes. There's no need for the wrench. It's just wasteful bloat. But I think they needed to cut most of the original weapons to allow their new ones to shine. 

* There were quite a lot of jumping and environmental puzzles. I quite liked them, but they weren't paced well with the combat, so they often felt tedious, and they all took place in those drab boxy environments. They also over-use box-smashing.

* Too much gman, ruining his mystique. 

It's kind of ironic that OP4 adds lots of stuff to HL, but rarely did it add anything worth remembering even 1 hour after playing it, let alone 20 years.

138071639.review: This is a great follow-up to the original Half-Life, building upon its predecessors in several key ways. For one, the platforming has been made much more manageable, as have the difficulty spikes. Some enemies are still damage sponges, but there's a greater variety of foes to defeat, each with wildly different attack patterns and quirks. The story isn't quite as interesting as its source material, but the soldier and security guard NPCs have a lot more character now, each with their own goals and personalities. Enemy placement is tough, but still more manageable than the original Half-Life; bosses and puzzles are more visually interesting and more engaging to figure out than Half-Life as well. This is all-in-all a very enjoyable expansion, and I'm sad that Valve haven't brought back Corporal Shephard or Race-X in any future titles. Hopefully we'll be able to visit the surprisingly robust boot-camp area again in a future game.

Half-Life: Opposing Force is an expansion pack for the original Half-Life game, released in 1999. The game follows the story of Adrian Shephard, a member of a military unit sent to clean up the Black Mesa Research Facility after the events of the original game.

One of the standout features of Half-Life: Opposing Force is its excellent storytelling. The game's narrative is well-crafted and engaging, with well-developed characters and an intriguing plot that expands on the Half-Life universe. The game's protagonist, Adrian Shephard, is a compelling character, and his journey through the Black Mesa facility is full of thrilling moments and unexpected twists.

The gameplay in Half-Life: Opposing Force is also top-notch, with a focus on action and combat. The game introduces new weapons, enemies, and gameplay mechanics that keep the gameplay fresh and exciting. The game's levels are well-designed, with a good balance of exploration and combat that keeps players engaged.

Another notable aspect of Half-Life: Opposing Force is its excellent level design. The game features a range of environments, from underground tunnels to sprawling research facilities, all of which are beautifully rendered and highly immersive. The game's sound design is also excellent, with a range of sound effects and music that add to the overall atmosphere of the game.

Overall, Half-Life: Opposing Force is an excellent addition to the Half-Life universe. It features engaging storytelling, excellent gameplay mechanics, and well-designed levels that offer a good balance of exploration and combat. If you're a fan of the Half-Life franchise, this expansion pack is well worth playing to experience the story of Adrian Shephard and his journey through the Black Mesa facility.

137591007.review:
An excellent campaign that was an enjoyable challenge to complete. I played this after Blue Shift - Blue Shift was very "meh" and quite pedestrian, whereas Opposing Force was a really nice alternative perspective on the Half-Life Black Mesa campaign.

This really reminded me why I liked the good bits from Half-Life - the gun play is really satisfying, with the variety of weapons making combat varied and interesting. I think overall this was tougher than in Half-Life, and if the campaign was too much longer, maybe IO'd have found it to be a slog. But no one section overstayed its welcome. Even the bits in Xen—which I *really* didn't enjoy in Half-Life—were okay; some of the platforming was frustrating, but again it didn't drag on too long.

The final boss was, of course, rubbish, and the feedback about doing real damage was a tad too subtle for my taste, but I don't think I faffed around for *toooooo* long not achieving anything.

I encountered some bugs that were a bit annoying - one was where weapons were unselectable, In think because the game didn't deem me to have picked them up (only having the space available in the inventory). This was annoying, but not major or showstopping. I also had the issue with the final teleporter after the final boss & had to select the final [scripted] chapter from the console. I'd have wated less time on this if I knew for certain this was a known bug!!

But overall, this was really enjoyable, and only made me look back on Half-Life a bit more fondly than I did immediately after playing that game (I really didn't like Xen.....!!) Great campaign! On to Half-Life 2 for me!

137394854.review:
REVIEW: Half-Life: Opposing Force
- Graphics -
personally, they're as good as they are, but by today's standards, they are really outdated.

- Gameplay -
it's your usual 1990s Valve FPS, there is a diverse amount of weapons to use, and you gotta shoot the aliens yeah.

- Difficulty -
normally, it starts out like any other game, quite not challenging, though the difficulty can really spike, especially in the later chapters, and once the Xen forces are gone, Lord be with you on Foxtrot Uniform..

- Requirements -
it's a 90s game bruh, a Windows 98 could run this thing.

- Story -
you, as Corporal Adrian Shephard, is sent on a mission to eliminate Freeman at Black Mesa, however it goes horribly wrong and unfortunately your homies couldn't survive the attack, the main focus of the game is really just fighting your way out of the Mesa.

- Music -
the music in the game, while not being that predominant (you'll likely be hearing silence during the game), is still pretty good.

- Does it top HL1? -
No, nothing will top the original Half-Life, however this game comes really close at that, it adds new content and new gameplay mechanics, like the Marines and the Race X, definitely better than the other HL1 expansions (Blue Shift and Decay).

SCORE: 8/10
Worth Buying? Absolutely.

136697462.review:
Half-Life: Opposing Force is everyone's darling. People adore this game, some going as far as saying it's not just better than the original, but one of, if not, the best game in the series, and I have to be honest, I'm not seeing what everyone else is seeing. Now, don't get me wrong, this is an excellent game, but I don't think it's the flawless masterpiece so many claim it is

The game is very ambitious, and adds a lot of new stuff. I think all the new weapons are great, but I could not care less for the new enemies. The new alien creatures are much more annoying and tough to kill than most of the originals, and I already hated the assassins, so fighting the black ops is always an absolute chore, made even worse by the fact that, unlike Half-Life, they are very common, and are mixed in with aliens at times.  These new enemies made me dread combat in general, which is sad because the new guns are probably my favorite aspect of this expansion

Enough negativity tho, there's much more positive here than negative. Level design is pretty solid, and feels very fresh. There's even some areas returning from the original Half-Life. Sure, the combat that takes place in them may make me want to never touch a videogame again, but the areas themselves are very cool and well designed. You also get help from your fellow marines, along with Black Mesa personel (mainly because Shephard didn't know he was meant to kill them.) It results in a game that makes you feel far less lonely, since you pretty much always have a buddy not too far away. Plus, the matines have great path finding, always have fun dialogue, and are genuinely useful in combat, along with being necessary for progression. The game is also much shorter than Half-Life, but is still longer than Blue Shift, landing in that perfect little sweet spot, at around the 5 hour mark for a casual playthrough. The campaign is also designed to be a mirror of Half-Life's, so you get a version of all your classic Half-Life set pieces, like the blast pit or Xen, while still distinguishing itself from the original

In general, I like Opposing Force, but I can't bring myself to love it. Personally, the combat is way too annoying, which is a big issue for an FPS game. That being said, it's a great game, and I wouldn't blame anyone for finding it better than the original, despite how much I dislike big aspects of it. Still, it's a fun game, and you should absolutely check it out

136537043.review:
This is an excellent expansion. It adds many new features to the game and continues building on the plot in a such a way that skipping it doesn’t hinder your understanding of the next entry.

The platoon mechanic is a neat idea, but a lot of its potential seems to be hindered by scripted events and navigational issues. Very rarely did a soldier follow me for more than a few corridors, let alone entire missions. I suppose I shouldn’t be surprised, though. After all, the game’s a quarter-century old and was already pushing the boundaries of the genre as a whole. Still, it's a little disappointing. In similar respects, the rope is also a cool addition, albeit extremely buggy. The grappling hook is another great addition. I think what I’m most surprised by is the fact that the devs remembered to add segments involving these features all throughout the game.

The expansion does have a few issues, though. The night vision goggles are a cool alternative to the flashlight, but in just about every scenario, you’ll end up turning it on for one short vent system, then turning it off again immediately after. The only time you’ll ever use it for an extended period is during the chapter ‘Foxtrot Uniform’, which is where I feel the expansion starts showing a massive decline in quality. Much like the original game, the last few chapters are very poorly designed. What you’ll find is essentially back-to-back gauntlets consisting of high-level enemies, all of which are severely lacking in ammo and even more so in health. It isn’t fun in any way and I hope whoever was responsible for coming up with the idea was given a stern talking to and forced to undergo a comprehensive shortcourse on level design.

One thing I’m a little curious about is in regards to the Powered Combat Vest. The tutorial showcases four different charging methods for this item, but during the course of the game, I didn’t find any commercial charging stations at all, and was only able to locate one military charging station. Maybe I didn’t look hard enough, maybe they just forgot. Either way, thought it was worth jotting down.

Overall, pretty enjoyable experience. If you liked the original game, you’ll probably like this one, too.

This is exactly how DLC should be made. Opposing Force is so good that it competes and even surpasses the original Half-Life in many occasions. Even something minor as the tutorial level, was enhanced drastically, it is completely different compared to what kind of tutorials we received with the main game and Blue Shift DLC, Opposing Force tutorial level is superior compared to what the other two have to offer.
Opposing Force claims to put you into the boots of an US.Marine and they deliver it way better than they had any right to deliver it in the first place. The story is good, we have tons of new weapons and most things have been made with the "military theme" in mind, which is just amazing, we also have new enemies (human and alien) and new allies, the story is not too short and not too long, just the right length. Soundtrack is absolutely amazing, even better than what the normal Half-Life had and what Blue Force gave in my opinion.
Opposing Force also gives us fresh gameplay features and good level design.
10/10 game, the only thing I was left of wanting more was fighting aliens with the military, since that part is kind of entirely skipped in this storyline, there is still some alien vs. HECU action, but it is pretty limited.

135719967.review:
For all the good things in here there's about 3 that annoy me. Opposing force has some fun weapons and is a neat side story to the original Half-Life that is fun for the first few hours.
 
After about the halfway point there isn't a single enemy encounter that isn't incredibly annoying with either way too many enemies thrown at you, too many overpowered enemies in one spot or just generally not giving you enough health pickups. All the difficulty feels either unfair or artificially induced from going to fights few little HP.

While the new weapons are fun, they're incredibly situational and mostly not as fun as what was in base HL. Also many seem to overlap in function far too much with other weapons in the game or are not distinct enough from the weapons they replaced from base HL. Overall the weapon sandbox feels a little confused and poorly thought out.

Only two of the new enemy types are remotely fun to fight, with the more fun of the two being hardly utilized. The others put the base game's most obnoxious foes to shame by a mile

To top it off the final boss is (admittedly far less annoying than base HL's) incredibly lame and far too easy

If you are in a pinch and desperate for more Half-life I suppose it would do, it's not awful. Just not something I ever see myself coming back to. If you snag this in a bundle I guess it's worth a shot but as for buying it on it's own, I'd just save the cash.

For instance, it expands on how the other side dealt with the situation and poses more questions about [spoiler]the nature of G-Man and the true importance of black mesa research.[/spoiler]

Additionally, the game allows you to have more than one NPC following you. As mentioned before, there are new guns, some bad, some very good. The new primary weapon also has different attacks from the original crowbar wich is very refreshing.

Overall, Opposing Force is a great game that truly enhances the value of the Half-Life franchise.

135518711.review:
En el Half-Life original, una “cascada de resonancia” abre una grieta dimensional, que hace que extraterrestres de Xen se teletransporten en Black Mesa.

Los científicos y los guardias de seguridad que sobreviven luchan para escaparse. Respondiendo rápidamente, los militares de Estados Unidos inician una operación masiva de “limpieza” para suprimir la presencia extraterrestre en el Black Mesa así como “silenciar” cualquier testigo. Cuando el juego comienza, el protagonista Adrian Shephard es parte de esta operación. Después de que su avión de transporte sea derribado y que el resto de su unidad muera, se aborta la misión de “limpieza” y Shephard reúne fuerzas con los supervivientes dispersados que buscan escape.

En su camino se encontrará con una hasta ahora desconocida raza, la "Raza X". Una raza hostil tanto a los humanos como a algunos tipos de Xenianos.

Mientras que la batalla comienza a favorecer al ejército extraterrestre, Shephard observa que las fuerzas militares han ordenado salir de allí. Las fuerzas de los Black Ops (vistos vagamente en el primer juego) están actuando independientemente de los infantes de marina; siendo enemigos tanto de HECU como de Black Mesa y los Xenianos; tratan de controlar la situación; pero esto claramente no es posible, y deciden hacer detonar Black Mesa con una bomba termonuclear. Shephard desactiva la bomba pero ve más adelante a G-Man que la reactiva.

Luego de que el protagonista Adrian Shephard logra vencer al extraterrestre proveniente de Xen éste es teletransportado a un avión (Osprey) similar al cual viajaba Adrian junto con otros cabos al principio, donde también se encuentra G-Man y le explica que debe dejarlo detenido en un lugar donde él no pueda revelar nada de lo ocurrido en los Laboratorios de Black Mesa.

Excelente extensión 11/10

135518064.review:
This Half-Life is a little odd. Gearbox Software and Valve Software are credited as co-creators of the game, but the game does not live up to the quality level set by the original Half-Life, or even the Half-Life expansion Half-Life: Blue-Shift of which I am a big fan. You reach a point in the game where you are fighting against are very strong aliens who don’t die easily, and you can’t even replenish your ammunition. Also during these moments, health pick-ups are rare. You’re facing marines more powerful than you. You pour bullets into them, but they’re still standing and shooting you. Though it seems alright at the start, the expansion pack really isn’t worth loading.

While the original Half-Life had serious puzzle solving, there is basically one puzzle in this game, though it was fun to solve. The final boss is neat, although amazingly, the game will not finish with OpenGL graphics selected. I was playing on Linux, and switched to the Windows machine to see the ending because the end of the game just doesn’t happen on Linux. I would have expected much better bug testing for such a high-profile franchise. Surely they could have made a patch?

Also disappointing are the lack of good music tracks. The original Half-Life was ahead of its time with quality techno / electronica, but I remember only one half-decent track, and that was all. Graphics are on par with the original, as you would expect.

This is my least favorite Half-Life.

134691034.review:
I first played through this as a teen, and after playing it again all these years later... I have forgot everything about it. Literally everything. I remembered absolutely nothing from my first playthrough, so for all Nintendos-and-Porpoises, I'm treating this like a first-time playthrough review.

Anyway, as someone who's grown sick of the Half-Life formula (both 1 and 2), due to the boring storytelling elements, unskippable garbage and environmental puzzles, I have to say that I'm surprised this expansion managed to hold my attention for its 5-hour runtime. The beginning, of course, is boring due to being forced to wait around pointlessly, but after that it's all pretty action-packed with some really good set pieces.

Minus a few hitscanner-heavy areas, it was all good fun and it did a good job stringing me along to the finish line. And that's a feat, because my patience is thin due to having a backlog with 400 games in it. I didn't expect to finish it, as I had originally intended on Alt+F4-ing during the intro helicopter ride and then telling myself I had given it the 'ole college try so that I could cross it off my backlog.

So would I recommend buying this, or playing this? Nah. It's bland and a little janky, and at times poory balanced, but overall I think it still manages to hold up. I'd only recommend playing this if you're out of boomer-shooters to play or if it's literally the last game in your backlog.

134634158.review:
Never reviewed a game on Steam, but I had to speak against the consensus on this one. HL1 is still a great game and mostly holds up today, but this outsourced (heh) expansion does not. 

I will probably play it to completion but my qualms so far are:

1. Environments are drab and boring: you're constantly wandering around a grey corridor listening to the same 1-second clip of electricity crackling. Very poor sense of atmosphere.

2. "Puzzles" are both cryptic and mind-numbing: often-times the solution to clearing a room is simply waiting for a scripted event to finish.

3. Horrible jump vertical: you need to crouch-jump to overcome a milk carton. Surely a soldier is more athletic than this? I know crouch-jump is in the original, but this game makes you jump on boxes constantly. 

4. Feels like a chore to play: I'm not given any motive except getting out of the aforementioned boring environments. 

5. I HATE the wrench. 

Positives:

1. New enemies are sort of cool. 

2. The knife is fun, but it's not our beloved crowbar.

Overall I would not recommend this Gearbox take on HL1, it feels very much a bootleg of the original rather than something which "expands" it.

133969408.review:
A game that's been around for quite some time, but it's still held in high regard by many gamers. That's right, I'm talking about Half-Life: Opposing Force. Now, before we dive into this, I have to say that I'm a huge fan of the original Half-Life game. It's one of the greatest first-person shooters ever made, and it's still a blast to play today. So, naturally, I was excited to check out Opposing Force and see if it could live up to the high standards set by the original game.

First off, let's talk about the story. In Opposing Force, you play as Adrian Shephard, a member of the military sent in to clean up the mess caused by Gordon Freeman in the original game. The game takes place in the same setting as the original game, but you'll be exploring new areas and encountering new enemies.

One thing that Opposing Force does really well is the way it expands on the lore of the Half-Life universe. You'll get to see more of the Black Mesa facility and learn more about the creatures that inhabit it. It's a nice touch that adds more depth to the world. But let's get to the gameplay. Opposing Force sticks to the same formula as the original game, with plenty of exploration, puzzles, and shooting. And I have to say, the shooting is just as satisfying as ever. The weapons all feel great to use, and the enemies are challenging without being frustrating.

The game also introduces some new gameplay mechanics, such as a grappling hook and a few new weapons. These additions are welcome, but they don't fundamentally change the gameplay in any significant way. They're just nice touches that add some variety to the experience.

Now, I do have to say that Opposing Force isn't perfect. There are a few moments where the game drags on a bit too long, and the final boss fight is a bit underwhelming. But these are minor quibbles in an otherwise fantastic game.

In conclusion, Half-Life: Opposing Force is a worthy companion piece to the original game. It expands on the lore in interesting ways, while still delivering the same great gameplay that made the original so beloved. If you're a fan of the Half-Life series, or just a fan of first-person shooters in general, you owe it to yourself to give Opposing Force a try.

133172495.review:
I'm not even really sure where to begin when reviewing a game like this. It's a real mixed bag, and complain as people may that Blue Shift wasn't as good, this game isn't so perfect either. I'll start by saying it's a really solid expansion pack for Half-Life, but I'll also add it's a seriously overambitious one as well. You'd think Gearbox were trying to make a full-on sequel! The main story goes on for a very long time, but this is hardly a bad thing. The amount of weapons you get is a little staggering, and I would have definitely cut out a decent portion of them. Do I really need a big, clunky wrench for two minutes before you give me the far superior knife anyway? And what's more, you even get new enemies to fight. Like I said, the game is overambitious, and also takes some liberties with the plot as well. (G-man seems to actively step into certain situations to either aid or impede the player, the Race X aliens are never seen/mentioned in any other Half-Life game, and we even witness the facility get freaking nuked.) 
I think my biggest issues with this expansion is its unbearable difficulty. I've beaten this game on hard, but even playing on medium is really unforgiving. Yeah, it's one of those games where they give you little to no health all the way through, but the odds are almost balanced out with all your weapons and ammo. But the brutal enemies (seriously, to hell with those shock troopers) mixed with some really basic, uninteresting level design only serve to piss me off. 
I do applaud the really close attention to detail here and there however - it's as though Gearbox realised how vivid Valve's game was and they wanted to mirror that. Once again though, they might have gone a little overboard. 
Adrian Shephard is quite an interesting character, probably second only to Gordon Freeman himself in levels of badass-ness. But enjoy him while he lasts here, because it's the last we'll ever see of him. 
I used to hold a big grudge against this game for its difficulty and very irritating Goldsource checkpoints that always seem to put you back twenty minutes, but I will admit it's better than Blue Shift. And not that it needed it, but we even have a multiplayer mode that is unfortunately dead. Some of the maps are really quite interesting, and for the first time we can even get a shot at playing capture-the-flag in Half-Life. 
I think what I'm trying to say is that Opposing Force has a ton of cool stuff - weapons, characters, a compelling story, cool enemies - but it perhaps goes a little too far. It is just an expansion at the end of the day, and I would still always recommend the main game over this in a heartbeat. Ironically, it's probably still the best game that Gearbox ever managed to produce, which is... depressing... but as a Half-Life game it really does excel.

Of course, this expansion is cool, playable and still feels amazing even after all those years. Adrian's story was liked by many. Yes, the expansions mimic the original narrative - Blast Pit / Pit Worm, final boss head shoot / belly shoot in the portal here, Nihilant spawning creatures / the green abomination spawning them too. However, Shepard's story shows the whole situation from a different angle, adding new elements (race X) and loads of other stuff (weaponary, half of which is seldom used). Anyways, for the time it was released it was awesome. And it is still awesome. Waiting for the remake!

132587942.review:
This one's really just more half-life. Focusing a bit more on fighting soldiers than the other bits; but it's all here.
The new added stuff fits in well, it shares the same clumsy spirit. The difficulty is comparable to mid-to-late HL for the most part. Playing blind and on hard I was crawling around at 10-30 hp a lot, but I never got stuck (testament to the viability of the tools given).
What's most impressive though, is the way the original game and these two expansions fit together as a whole. You'll rarely see additional content fit in so snugly like it was part of the main package all along. All 3 campaigns happen concurrently and you see bits and pieces of the other events from the perspective of the one you're in, often passing through the same locations at different times and different ways. The fact they're color-coded makes a lot of sense, as adding a bit more color to HL1 is what these expansions succesfully do.
Good stuff. Surprisingly not overrated.

One of my favorite Half-Life expansion pack on series, This pack adds new weapons: M249, M40 Sniper Rifle, Desert Eagle and etc.
A single player campaign is short, You play as Adrian Shepard. a Corporal HECU soldier who sent mission on Black Mesa and must eliminate new alien threat called Race X.
There are new NPCs on this pack are introduced to: Male Black Ops assassin, Race X Aliens, Otis, HECU Medic & Engineer.
You can also play Multiplayer mode on a expansion with your friends, These servers are active for now.
